name: Neal Miller
body:
## Experience
__Learning Analytics Engineer__  
Reasoning Mind, Houston, TX  
_March 2013 — present_  
* Developing a diagnostic system by which student knowledge is modeled and gaps in prerequisite knowledge are addressed.
* Developed detectors of student behavior and affective state using educational data mining.
* Analyzing student data to inform future product development.

Senior Analyst July 2012 — August 2013Reasoning Mind, Houston, TX

Designed and improvde the business processes by which staff work with each other and with those served by the organization. Interviewed stakeholders, designed processes, trained employees, and maintained implemented processes.
Administered and developed for of the companys Salesforce.com organization, used for most business processes throughout the organization. Developed applications and processes to expand this functionality into other areas; for example, marketing and hiring.
Fellow February 2011 — May 2012Columbia Technology Ventures, New York, NY

Assisted in the assessment and licensing of intellectual property held by Columbia University.
Graduate Research Assistant August 2007 — May 2012

Columbia University in the City of New York, New York, NY
Adviser: Angelo Cacciuto
Wrote Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulations for the study of self-assembly in soft matter systems
Undergraduate Research Assistant August 2004 — May 2007

The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX
Adviser: Paul F. Barbara
Education
Columbia University in the City of New York, New York, NY
May 2012
May 2011
May 2008

Ph.D., Chemical Physics, with Distinction
M.Phil, Chemical Physics
M.A., Chemical Physics
Dissertation: Self-organization in systems of anisotropic particles

The University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX
May 2007

B.S., Chemistry, Honors
Thesis: Single-molecule spectroscopic studies of conjugated polymers

Skills
Salesforce.com administration
Salesforce.com development
APEX
Visualforce
Programming
C
Java
Python
Linux
Microsoft Office products
Data Mining
Student modeling
Feature engineering and extraction
Machine Learning
RapidMiner
Publications
W. L. Miller, B. Bozorgui, K. Klymko, and A. Cacciuto Free energy of alternating two-component polymer brushes on cylindrical templates. J. Chem. Phys 135, 244902 (2011). (preprint)
W. L. Miller and A. Cacciuto. Two-dimensional packing of soft particles and the soft generalized Thomson problem. Soft Matter 7, 7552 (2011). (preprint)
W. L. Miller and A. Cacciuto. On the phase behavior of hard aspherical particles. J. Chem. Phys. 133, 234903 (2010). (preprint)
W. L. Miller and A. Cacciuto. Exploiting classical nucleation theory for reverse self-assembly. J. Chem. Phys. 133, 234108 (2010). (preprint)
W. L. Miller, B. Bozorgui, and A. Cacciuto. Crystallization of hard aspherical particles. J. Chem. Phys. 132, 134901 (2010). (preprint)
B. Bozorgui, M. Sen, W. L. Miller, J. C. Pàmies, and A. Cacciuto. Phase behavior of repulsive polymer-tethered colloids. J. Chem. Phys. 132, 014901 (2010). (preprint)
R. E. Palacios, W.-S. Chang, J. K. Grey, W. L. Miller, C.-Y. Liu, G. Henkelman, D. Zepeda, J. Ferraris, and P. F. Barbara. Detailed single-molecule spectroelectrochemical studies of the oxidation of conjugated polymers. J. Phys. Chem. B 113, 14619 (2009).
W. L. Miller and A. Cacciuto. Hierarchical self-assembly of asymmetric amphiphatic spherical colloidal particles. Phys. Rev. E 80, 021404 (2009). (preprint)
S.-J. Park, S. Link, W. L. Miller, A. Gesquiere, and P. F. Barbara. Effect of electric field on the photoluminescence intensity of single CdSe nanocrystals. Chem. Phys. 341, 169 (2007).
J. K. Grey, D. Y. Kim, B. C. Norris, W. L. Miller, and P. F. Barbara. Size-dependent spectroscopic properties of conjugated polymer nanoparticles. J. Phys. Chem. B 110, 25568 (2006).
J. K. Grey, D. Y. Kim, C. L. Donley, W. L. Miller, J. S. Kim, C. Silva, R. H. Friend, and P. F. Barbara. Effect of temperature and chain length on the bimodal emission properties of single polyfluorene copolymer molecules. J. Phys. Chem. B 110, 18898 (2006).
